threads.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

last_replies.com:
I went to an all-boys boarding school (plus had a fairly distant relationship with my father and overly close one with my mother) which caused a lot of adolescent attraction to other boys. However, as soon as I got to uni and realised that girls actually existed (outside of internet pornography, which unfortunately had been my main exposure to them), I began to realise after about a year and a bit that I was lying to myself and was actually always attracted to girls. I sort of knew this, but I convinced myself that I was only capable of same-sex romantic attraction because that was all I had known previously, and it was also a convenient way of ignoring self-esteem issues which convinced me I wouldn’t be capable of getting attractive girls. It actually took a girl — who unfortunately I wasn’t interested in — taking me out on three dates until I realised that I could be attractive to some girls, and even then it took a couple of months to realise what I actually wanted and change my Tinder settings to women.
I don’t think I’m typical of most ‘formerly homosexual’ people at all, although the experience of people going to non-co-ed boarding schools and developing attractions to the same sex that they then grow out of is fairly common. I still feel attraction to feminine looking men, but I don’t think there’s anything wrong with that, I just don’t act on it, mainly because there are a higher number of attractive women and also because having a woman in one’s life is more of a sense of achievement and fulfilment. Check your digit ratios, whether you have gay voice, whether you have ever experienced attraction to women — if you have a high digit ratio and almost never experienced anything other than same-sex attraction then it might just be genetic and something you just have to accept about yourself, if you have low digit ratio and have experienced attraction to women before, it’s more likely to be a case of inhibiting psychological factors. There’s nothing wrong with homosexuality if it’s natural for you, but if it’s because you’re genuinely confused then it may prevent you from living the most fulfilling life you can.

Haven't seen Culture of Critique mentioned unless it's in one of those shitty infographs I never read. That's a travesty and a key to understanding a lot of what's going on in the world today. Definitely an eye-opener for the uninitiated.For a more balanced worldview I'd recommend Ship of Fools by Tucker Carlson, The Divide and Griftopia by Matt Taibbi, Death of the West by Pat Buchanan, and Camp of the Saints by Jean Raspail. All great in their own right.

For some entertainment purposes, Hunter and The Turner Diaries are fun if not particularly well-written, and Siege reads like a schizophrenic's diary. If you're looking for mindless brutality written by folks exposed as actual federal agents for the express purpose of radicalizing potential domestic terrorists, Iron Gates (I think that's what it's called) is kind of a WN version of an Edward Lee book replete with rape and torture. Adjustment Day by Palahniuk is an ambitious and entertaining read, but the execution of a great idea admittedly leaves something to be desired.

If you want something heavier, go with just about anything from David Irving. Hitler's War is probably his masterpiece, but his Goebbels's biography is great as well. Hitler's Table Talk is also a good read, although I've heard its veracity has been called into question on more than one occasion. Of course read Mein Kampf. Can't go wrong with Machiavelli either.

Saving the best for last, Jim Goad's Redneck Manifesto might be my all-time favorite book of any genre. You'll laugh, learn, be pissed off and you'll likely come back to it for another reading at least once a year. Outstanding writer and a 10/10 book. You won't be disappointed, particularly if you come from a middle class/lower middle class background and are sick of being blamed for all of society's ills despite a life of despair and constant recriminations despite yielding no institutional power whatsoever.

Hope you find something you like in there, anon. Happy reading.

[For anyone else reading, spoilers for The Shining ahead]

I just finished the book, and I don't really think that what you say is true.
Jack is not really shown as a good dad or a good teacher; he breaks his son's arm, he has very obvious anger issues that make him threatening and unreliable, on top of his addiction that makes him even worse. The only thing that makes it look like he's a good dad is because Danny is a daddy's boy, just like how Jack was to his dad (and his dad was an obviously terrible person to everyone except Jack, who just happened to be his favourite).
At school Jack is very lousy as well: he teaches while being hangover or still being drunk 90% of the time when he teaches in the morning, the other teachers hate and avoid him (except for Al, and that's just because they are drinking buddies and are both alcoholics).
The only positive aspects of his career as a teacher is his debate club (which he fucks up in the end) and his small writing career, which isn't even directly a teacher thing since he's writing on the side, and his 'fame' was only like one story that got featured in a big magazine or something similar.

Jack is a complex character: he is trying his best to be a good person, but he is heavily struggling with addiction, he has very serious anger issues without any way to talk about it or improve himself (other than just telling himself not to lose his temper), when he should obviously get therapy (which he doesn't get because he's the man and he can fix everything himself, he doesn't talk about his feelings or problems at all. The first time he actually talks about his problems in all those years is when the three of them go to the doctor to see if there's anything wrong with Danny.) He has closed off his emotions to such an extreme degree that he has only said "I love you" to his wife less than 10 times in his whole life.

He is trying really hard to do the right thing and be a good person, but he just doesn't know how. That's how the Hotel manages to get to him: his biggest weaknesses are his addiction, his anger issues, his money problems, and the love for his father, who was an abusive, alcoholic, violent asshole, and the Hotel uses all those mental problems/weaknesses to make him believe he should kill Danny.

Wendy and Danny know Jack is being corrupted by the Hotel, and they both love him despite his faults, problems and struggles. Wendy had been thinking about divorce for a long time, but going to this Hotel might be the solution to get everything back on track and create the perfect family. At first, everything is actually going better, but the Hotel brings out the absolute worst in Jack, and at some point it is so extreme that it is obvious to Wendy and Danny that Jack is gone and it's just the Hotel now. They don't see Jack as an angel, but they see him as a person who doesn't deserve to get turned into a mindless murder monster by the Hotel.

Time for Night Shift now!

>Charlotte Mary Mew (15 November 1869 – 24 March 1928) was an English poet whose work spans the eras of Victorian poetry and Modernism.
>Her poems are varied: some of them (such as "Madeleine in Church") are passionate discussions of faith and the possibility of belief in God; others are proto-modernist in form and atmosphere ("In Nunhead Cemetery"). She made experimental use of long, prose-like lines, and varieties of enjambment and indentation, which has been praised for its originality. Many of her poems are in the form of dramatic monologues, and she often wrote from the point of view of a male persona ("The Farmer's Bride"). Two concern mental illness – "Ken" and "On the Asylum Road". Many of Mew's poems, including "Ken", "The Farmer's Bride", and "Saturday Market", are about outcast figures, expressing Mew's feelings of alienation from the community in which she lived. Her poem "The Trees Are Down" is a poignant plea for ecological sensitivity and is singled out particularly in the anthology The Green Book of Poetry by Ivo Mosley.
>Mew gained the patronage of several literary figures, notably Thomas Hardy, who called her the best woman poet of her day; Virginia Woolf, who said she was "very good and interesting and quite unlike anyone else"; and Siegfried Sassoon. In 1923, she obtained a Civil List pension of £75 per year with the aid of Cockerell, Hardy, John Masefield, and Walter de la Mare. This helped ease her financial difficulties.

When somebody flippantly says that MGS2 isn't deep or that it didn't come up with anything new are they actually meaningfully contributing to the conversation at all? That's not to say it was the first, but that it still is a meaningful piece of historical writing about our future.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Social science can’t really be something fundamentally different than what it is. The issue is that it basically became the master science because no one is willing to challenge the notion that society and secondarily economics form all of human reality. That’s the intellectual framework required to justify blank slate theory and the Accident of Birth idea which are unquestionable dogma in the West. Formerly, social scientists had strict limitations placed on the scope of their work by competing explanations of human reality coming from the religious sphere and the biological science sphere. The priest says “that’s all well and good but actually God says this”, the biologist says “that’s all well and good but it looks like we do have immutable instincts and it looks like G determines life outcomes”. With explanations like this being fringe and taboo in the culture, the social scientist comes to the (accurate) conclusion that his discipline must be capable of explaining absolutely everything. This brings with it tremendous hubris and the idea that society can be “directed” and “fixed” by those with social scientific knowledge, which is the justification for the indefinite expansion of state and private bureaucracies attempting to do just that that others in this thread have already pointed out

Austria-Hungary is interesting, and can help demonstrate my point. It had nations (which are good), but was not a nation state (which are bad). It was also not ethnically homogenous, unless you move down to a smaller scale. This second feature also describes the US. So why were a subset of Austria-Hungary’s multi-national institutions (religious, educational, military) able to work (and boy, did they), while the Balkans imploded into nationalistic violence and the US’ institutions visibly disintegrate? It’s plainly not the somatic characteristics of the participants, because in both societies there is strong evidence of multi-ethnic cooperation in the periods preceding decline.
I think the contemporary sociologistic worldview cannot possibly answer this question, because the answer has to do with *meaning*: a kind of shared-interiority, or metaphysical integration with reality which is explicitly and intentionally rejected as meaningless by the scientistic worldview because it is not, finally, manipulable by technique.

threads.com:
1) Language is primarily in relation to what is linguistically expressible immanently through sense data.

2) As language is contingent on sense data (experience), knowledge of transcendental manners beyond the immanence of sense data is a place where language has no domain

3) Thus, any talk of transcendental affairs and abstract concepts of things that are beyond experience already presuppose language, which is predicated on experience, which finds meaning in experience in relation to a motivation

4) Thus, concepts outside experience (life after death, God, supernatural entities, etc.) are contrived from the mind, and since said concept presupposes language, which is predicated on experience and finds meaning fundamentally from experience

5) Ergo, for a riddle that has no answer is necessarily nonsensical, thus is illogical

6) “*The limits of my language are the limits of my world* (Tractus Logico-philosophicus, Wittgenstein). The limit of the world is what is experienced.

7) The subject is the limit of the world for experience is all that is in the world of the subject

Schopenhauer outlines how intuitive perception is the basis of all knowledge and that all concepts are mediated through intuitive perception which lead to concepts, concepts being thought in the mind and abstracted upon further and further to concepts of God therefore ignore that the concept they have contrived is predicated on experience, it is then erroneous to assign abstract concepts and thoughts originating from intuitive perception as ‘truthful’ if they do not have a corresponding object that can be found in experience. Hegel conflated *thinking* itself and concepts were to be identical with the essence of things, therefore every abstract concept which originated from intuitive perception from which all knowledge originates is now true. And now from there Hegel said that now the Dialectical self-movement of a concept was now to be the revelation of all things, that contradictions make up every concept (obviously transcendental speculation is contradictory with immanently available knowledge). After Schelling had given the world the title of God, Hegel took this literally and ascribed the world with omniscience, and since the world is god, the dialectical self-movement of abstract concepts (thoughts) was God trying to know itself and all the mysteries of the world; anyone not fooled into conflating obscure jargon filled prolixity of Hegel with that of profundity would know how stupid this idea is. From above, any concept transcending experience already presupposes language, which is contingent on experiential data. All that can be linguistically expressible is what experienced and any concept without experience is mere intellectual play.

threads.com:
If a person or society is, all the time, insulated from ever 'really' suffering, how would that person or that society ever be able to recognize the worth of things which are good and simple?

A Man or Woman could not, perhaps, understand the great fun and joy in "all things" until, perhaps, they have been put in a prison for a very long time or in some other way been made to suffer horribly. It is not that "ending" that suffering brings joy to them but that they see the whole world with new eyes; cherishing then what they had despised or not even recognized before. It is a strange thing to consider the spoiled child of a suddenly rich person; they seek to prevent the child from ever needing to want or suffering, as consequence they raise a creature who is dehumanized and seeks only to consume, which itself seems merely a larval state - as the birth of the person has been prevented from coming about; they demand to feed on the pap regurgitated for them and they writhe around - both literally and allegorically in all things that they do.

Indeed, it is the action of the self which is required to cut loose from the cocoon; an action of first true consciousness.

I don't mean "artificial" in the sense of "the activity itself is utterly pointless". That will only cause resentment. I mean "artificial" in the sense of "there is an activity which needs doing which is arduous / taxing / risky, and everyone should have to do it for a bit, even people who are theoretically rich enough to avoid it (e.g. by paying someone else to do it for them)".

To take the National Service idea as the obvious example: Let's assume you need an army. Instead of just having a class (or underclass) of private soldiers to take your risks for you, ALL the young men have to do it for a bit. This is sort of what Heinlein was saying in Starship Troopers — "If you don't serve in the military and risk your life, you don't get to vote."

It's easy to see how this might get eroded. People would say "well, what if we have some genius mathematician or violinist or something. We don't want to risk HIM; so those people get special exemption". But once you introduce that, all the rich people will make sure their children get exemption. It would be hard to enforce.


It was easier to do this sort of thing in the past because there was so much more legitimate opportunity / need for hardship. There was a huge amount of heavy lifting to be done, and really NOT having to do it was the very artificial lifestyle. These days it's the other way around.

>>21266504
It's fun to use Latin phrases casually. Don't tiptoe respectfully round them; weave them into the text. (Schopenhauer does this quite a bit.)


LATIN: "Caedite eos. Novit enim Dominus qui sunt eius." ("Kill them all. God knows which are His.")
USEAGE: There may be a few honest journalists amongst the scoundrels. Too bad. Caedite eos, I say. Novit enim Dominus qui sunt eius.

LATIN: "ipse dixit" ("I have said it"; i.e. a pronouncement made with no supporting evidence or argument)
USEAGE: Baudrillard sometimes says interesting things, but as with all Marxists, his ipse dixit arrogance at critical points quickly becomes insufferable.


Or you can break bits off and use them in your own sentences. You have to know which word means which thing, but there's no harm in getting the grammar wrong. It's up to Latin to adapt to English, not the other way around.


LATIN: "noli me tangere" ("touch me not" — Vulgate John 20:17)
USEAGE: There she sat with her babycham and her noli me tangere expression, but it was pretty obvious that if someone didn't tangere her soon she was going to explode.


You don't have to stick to prose. Light verse which mixes up different languages = 'macaronic verse':


LATIN: "de minimis non curat lex" ("the law does not concern itself with trifles")
USEAGE: A lecherous rascal named Rex / Uncovered his organ of sex: / But the judge let him go, / Saying "Surely you know / That de minimis non curat lex".

threads.sub: /fic/ storytime : the ghast employer and how the revolution began
threads.com:
Jim found himself in his employers office, holding a list of grievances co-signed by the staff of his floor. What had brought him to this point? The ill-stewardship of his employer, yes, and the many foolish impositions put upon him and his colleagues; all none related to the work but imposed as it were merely to grind-down the will into submission. He had not expected, however, his employer to utter the words that came now,

"I will replace you all with black people," were what the employer simply said, with a look of disassociative serenity, "and perhaps women as well."

Jim was thrown off balance by this and he spun all around like a spinning-top and crashed into the wall. He cried out in terror and then he saw his employer, while having moved not at all, was now levitating with his desk and chair and nearing ever closer to Jim. The small mouth of his employer turned into a chasming maw and ghostly reverberations sounded from within the pit of his tummy, "but I cannot let you leave, knowing of my plans."

Suddenly the door to the office burst open and the employer gave a long guttural hiss.

"Arthur!" cried Jim, extending an arm to the only black colleague in the building.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
"Gosh!" exclaimed Arthur, "I feared all along that our employer was one of them," and he tore a shotgun from his back, "Jim," he said, a bead of sweat falling from his brow to his spectacles, "he means to replace us all with ghetto blacks, he was never an equal opportunist who did not see race - he hired me," he said, "thinking I was a pliant sort who would acquiesce! He meant to elevate me and when I said 'NO, I WILL NOT' he said I would regret it, but," and Arthur aimed the shotgun, "who will regret what, Mr. Cavendish?"

Jim snarled at the employer, "we've got you now," he chuckled.

Mr. Cavendish hovered mid-air, as if appraising the situation, "no," he said, "there is no means by which you will win here. You may kill me but another exactly like me will be sent from head office," and he smiled, "we are merely worker bees; wasps if you will, serving our hive queen. You Americans are nothing. We are sustained by psychokinetic energies, purest vitae from the screaming mouths of babes."

Jim gasped, Arthur gasped. It was a thing they had always secretly suspected but never given voice to before.

"it may be true, what you say, Mr. Cavendish," said Jim, "but you've forgotten one little thing."

"And what is that?!" roared Mr. Cavendish, his beige lips forming a disgusting visage, an expression of insatiable lust which then turned to terror at what Jim now held in his hand.

"just a little book by Thomas Jefferson," drawled Jim.

Mr. Cavendish inhaled deeply, "now just wait," but it was too late.

No sooner had Jim begun to read from the Founding Documents then Mr. Cavendish lost his spell and his desk and chair clattered to the soft carpeted flooring, leaving him all of a sudden impotent.

"My magics," he complained, as like a spoiled child whose ball had been taken from him by a school master, "this is cringe," he said.

"And now," shouted Arthur, using his agility to leap to the top of the desk in a single bound, "the consequence and remedy!" and he stuck the barrel of the shotgun into Mr. Cavendish's face, and Jims pleads of reason went unheard under verses of Heart of Oak until the crescendo was reached and Arthur blew Mr. Cavendish's apart like a wet sack.


Jim fell to his knees, "violence," he breathed, "now we have lost morally," and he hung his head.

"Not so," said Arthur, "for did not General LayFayette do likewise unto the rebels?"

Jim looked up, a glimmer in his eye, "he did," and then he bounded to his feet, "by jove," he cried, "HE DID."


The Men embraced as brothers-in-arms as in the distance the wail of foreign sirens drew nearer. The wasps of Cavendish were on their way; thinking they came to apprehend mere lambs they would not reckon on the discipline and efficiency by which Jim and Arthur would dispatch them beforehand. After all, there were only a few hundred lobsterbacks in the city. When they were done away with the black quarter would dine on lobster stew.


fin.
id. ix epulum iovis. nov.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21266123
Kant didn't even come up with it, he copied it from Leibnitz's Essays on Metaphysics where Leibnitz made the distinction between an essential truth whose truth is determined via the law of non-contradiction and a contingent truth whose truth is determined "ex hypothesi", ie dependent upon "God's will", which is contingent (unnecessary) circumstances, ie synthetically connecting things which don't have to be connected. It's valid as far as that goes, Kant's problem was dividing the judgements into a priori and a posteriori, which is something he also took from Leibnitz and modified into a slightly different form.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21266998
>which is something he also took from Leibnitz and modified into a slightly different form.
how?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21267672
Because Kant assumed that there was an intrinsic divide between the human mind and reality, whereas Leibnitz was correct in asserting that reality itself is contained within the monad which is an intelligent being, which is the only way any intelligent being can even make predictions about the phenomena it perceives (which we actually do). Leibnitz argues quite persuasively that the only difference between an a priori and posteriori truth is that a priori comes from having entire knowledge of a concept (given that human beings as such, and their entire universal destiny, are contained in their monadic concept, along with the substance they are typically accustomed to, namely physical reality, which is just one perspective of God's, there being indefinitely many perspectives and substances, all created through God's vision/glory). Therefore an a posteriori judgement is one formulated about a concept of which one only has incomplete information, not a judgement which is given specifically "empirically" as opposed to transcendentally, which Kant argued.

The Kid raped and killed the Judge theory

The kid, dissatisfied after being unable to get hard with the dwarf prostitute, went into the outhouse and found the judge and the missing girl and decided to rape and kill the both of them, when the judge is dancing afterwards he is doing the dance of death because he is literally dead, but now that the kid has decided to kill the judge, the judges philosophy lives on in the kid which is exactly what he wanted hence why he is happy to do the dance, hence the "i will live forever" quote.
During the confrontation at the desert creekbed earlier in the book the judge doesn't shoot the kid, he shoots the priest, specifically in the throat in an attempt to silence the ex-priest and remove his ability to influence the kid, because he never wanted to kill the kid but to convert him to his philosophy of "war is god" and for the kid to cease being a fence sitter that is not fully committed to the slaughter the judge proposes, at that point the judges inability to convert the kid into a mindless killing machine like he managed with most of the rest of the gang was the judges biggest failure, but the kid deciding to kill the judge and the girl allows the judges philosophy to live on within the kid. To kill the kid means the judge has failed to propagate his ideas.

Kid converts to judges philosophy voluntarily = judge wins
kid kills judge = judge wins
judge kills kid = judge loses

if the judge were to kill the kid it would signal the judges demise as he has failed to convert the kid and with the rest of the glanton gang that fully committed to the slaughter dead it means that he has failed to propagate his ideology as all his adherents have been extinguished. The judge is doing the dance of death because although he has lived, his failure to convert the kid signals his demise and death philosophically, while the judge may of survived, his ideas haven't, like the buffalo he will be facing extinction. The men who embrace his ideas are continually snuffed from existence (akin to the buffalo being slaughtered faster than they could reproduce) and with the kid dead his known followers have been reduced to nil. As the hunters with their guns and wagons full of lead heading west as described by the old hunter meant the end of the buffalo, the westward expansion of the men digging the holes along with their presumed steel posts and barbed wire fences in the epilogue represents the technological innovations enabling the further encroachment of civilisation that is coming to bring an end to the judge.

considering the latter is the bad ending for the judge, and the judge seemed rather happy at the end of the novel, it stands to reason it was the first theory that comes to pass, the kid killed the judge.

Is it possible to harness the power of Adorno's f-scale to make subliminally reactionary children's literature? What do you think?

> The California F-scale is a 1947 personality test, designed by Theodor W. Adorno and others to measure the "authoritarian personality".[1] The "F" stands for "fascist". The F-scale measures responses on several different components of authoritarianism, such as conventionalism, authoritarian aggression, superstition and stereotypy, power and "toughness", destructiveness and cynicism, projectivity, and sex. Scores acquired from the F-scale could be directly associated with background components, educational level, and intellectual capacity.[2] It is an indirect type of test that ensures the result would not be due to the individual's fake responses; this is possible because the purpose of the measurement and which attitude is being measured are initially concealed from the participants.[3] The existence of this correlation could possibly affect the way in which the F-scale accurately measures the authoritarian personality syndrome.[2] The F-scale has two principal purposes: it aims to measure prejudice and anti-democratic tendencies at the personality level.[3]

>The scale specifically examines the following personality dimensions:
>Conventionalism: conformity to the traditional societal norms and values of the middle class;
>Authoritarian submission: a passive notion towards adhering to conventional norms and values;
>Authoritarian aggression: punishing and condemning individuals who don’t adhere to conventional values;
>Religion and Ethics;
>Superstition
>Power and "toughness";
>Anti-intraception, i.e. "rejection of all inwardness, of the subjective, the imaginative, the tender-minded, and of self-criticism";
>Destructiveness and Cynicism: Generalized hostility, vilification of the human;
>Projectivity: The disposition to believe that wild and dangerous things go on in the world; the projection outwards of unconscious emotional impulses; and
>Sex: Exaggerated concern with sexual "goings-on."

threads.com: Are we really going to take Plato's caricature of Thrasymachus seriously? The entirety of book 1 is a testament to Socrates's definitive sophistry. In particular I am vexed by his insistence that things are useless when not actively in use. That is absurd. Or that doing good for your charge must mean you arent acting selfishly. Thrasymachus's argument that a ruler shall do good to his subjects for his own benefit is indisputable. Why Plato did his song and dance of a tangent about a "good ruler," is beyond me. It added very little to the syllogism on Justice. And if we take the recording at Plato's word, then Socrates's sheer incompetence, requiring the others present to explain Thrasymachus's distinction between INTEREST and IDEAL, makes him out to be disingenuous at worst and ignorant at best.

threads.com:
I was thinking about what makes art art. And I think I came up with a very succinct, all-encompassing definition. Simpler definitions are better than very elaborate ones, who have to deal with a lot of exceptions.

Art is self-contained. A picture, a book, a musical piece are self-contained entities. There are no expansion packs for a book or a DLC for music. They are judged on their own. Context might help you to appreciate and understand them better, but the other work of an artist are all separate self-contained art pieces.

This is why games, tv shows, comics, etc are not art. Because they are not self-contained. This is why the upper class had such disdain for penny dreadfuls, who started the trend of not telling self-contained stories, but having the same protagonist, like a detective for example, always encountering new monsters, finding new lover interests, repeating the same themes over and over again. A game's lore and universe can always be ruined by a sequel, who in an effort to subvert expectations now tells you how the evil enemy you fought all along were actually dindu nuffins. Or how a culture, where all of the druids are male and the all of the priestess are female now has men in dresses and female furries.
